discussion_comments.comment_body:
Shouldn't they be declared after the check line 338?
Currently they use memory even if they don't have any use

Also it could be nice to directly add value and depth when declaring for performance 

<details>
<summary>Benchmark (~2.25x faster)</summary>

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/03f98fc8-836d-4b7d-b819-b6059625216d)

https://jsbenchmark.com/#
</details>
yes , you are right。 I will move these two lines to the bottom

commented_code:
return false
   }
 
-  return key in el
+  return camelize(key) in el || key in el

     return false
   }
 
-  return key in el
+  return camelize(key) in el || key in el
discussion_comments.comment_body:
Maybe we can cache camelKey on el like this:       
```js  
const camelKey = camelize(key)
if (camelKey in el) {
  ;(el as any)[`$${key}`] = camelKey
  return true
}
```
`patchProp` changes as follows
```js
patchDOMProp(el, el[`$${key}`] || key, nextValue, parentComponent)
```

Call `camelize` only once, check `in` only once

discussion_comments.comment_body: We could use a `symbol` as key too... either to set directly the value of the current prop being set (would get overwritten by every new attribute being set and not cached across renders) or use it to create an object where properties could then be referenced by their specific key and thus caching the results. Or we leave it as you suggested above. Thoughts?

discussion_comments.commented_code:
@@ -140,5 +142,5 @@ function shouldSetAsProp(
     return false
   }
 
-  return key in el
+  return camelize(key) in el || key in el
discussion_comments.comment_body:
> Should we actually add a check for that and what to do if it already exists?

We just need to use a key that is as unlikely to duplicate as possible, such as `$_v_prop_${key}` or symbol as key.
I think only the camel key need to be cached.

The reason I did that way was to avoid unnecessarily executing this line when the check in the previous line returns `undefined`:

https://github.com/vuejs/core/pull/13085/files/b4bdb6db27cc9962663d2b327b438fe0fb8aa0e2#diff-51bf3d2247157ea7e415bdcf74feabbe5843467638c131743785ab6c68640605R53

Based on the current changes, I think your initial commit was actually better. This logic is far more costly than a single 'in' check. Moreover, your original approach didn't always perform two 'in' checks—it only did so when `shouldSetAsProp` was executed. Perhaps the initial commit is more appropriate. I'm really sorry for misleading you.
No worries, I'll revert back to the first commit. Thanks for the review and the suggestions!

I don't think this is necessary, because the parameters passed in by the user are uncontrollable. The parameters passed in by the user may all be responsive objects. Only use toRaw to process the first parameter. If the subsequent parameters are responsive objects, Incur access tracking overhead

> I don't think this is necessary, because the parameters passed in by the user are uncontrollable. The parameters passed in by the user may all be responsive objects. Only use toRaw to process the first parameter. If the subsequent parameters are responsive objects, Incur access tracking overhead

The purpose here is to use the original value to re-check whether it exists, so only the first parameter needs to be toRaw, and other parameters do not require additional processing. At the same time, the modification here will not cause additional overhead, because before executing this code, it will execute `const res = arr[key](...args)`
I think it would be great if we could add or point out a test case to clarify it further.
Would it perhaps be better to check `_runnings` first, try to avoid calling `dep.get(effect)` at all?
Thanks for pointing that out! I've made the changes.
